trial_identification.studytitle: Models of care for Acute Non-invasive Ventilation- Comparison of three tertiary Centres.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Three Acute non-invasive ventilation services based in metropolitan Melbourne in the hospital ward (The Alfred Hospital), high dependency unit (Royal Melbourne Hospital) and intensive care unit (Boxhill Hospital) deliver equivalent patient outcomes and are equally cost effective.

conditions.healthcondition: Comparison of models of care for acute non-invasive ventilation across three tertiary centres.

interventions.interventions: Prospective observational non-inferiority study comparing the acute non-invasive ventilation services (NIV) at The Alfred, Royal Melbourne and Boxhill Hospital. All patients received their usual care. Usual care included all medications required to treat an exacerbation of COPD including controlled oxygen, steriods (either inhaled/ oral or Intra venously), current inhaled respiratory medications and antibiotics if required. Inclusion criteria- Adult patients admitted with Acute exacerbation of chronic pulmonary disease (AECOPD) by standard criteria (GOLD) complicated by acute respiratory acidosis. Exclusion criteria- Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) patients treated with non-invasive ventilation for weaning post mechanical ventilation. The study duration was 14 months.
interventions.comparator: Prospective observational non-inferiority study comparing three acute NIV services of equal weight, treating patients admitted with acute exacerbation of COPD complicated by respiratory acidosis.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Increase in PH with Non invasive ventilation (NIV) treatment for Acute exacerbation of chroninc obstructive pulmonary disease (AECOPD) complicated by respiratory acidosis (3 centre comparison).
primaryOutcome.timepoint: 14 months of data collection March 2011 to may 2012.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The aim is to compare three different acute non invasive ventilation services in three tertiary centres in Melbourne. All data has been collected on a password protected microsoft access database. Only a select few have the password. This study is a prospective observational study all patients received their usual care and data is de identified.
